title: In-class Exercise 1: Now You See It!
text:
##Loading R packages
In this hands-on exercise, two R packages will be used. They are:
The code chunk used is as follows:
pacman::p_load(tidyverse,haven)

title: In-class Exercise 1: Now You See It!
text:
Importing PISA data
The code chunk below uses read_sas() of haven to import PISA data into R environment.

# eval: false
stu_qqq <- read_sas("data/cy08msp_stu_qqq.sas7bdat")


# eval: false
stu_qqq_SG <- stu_qqq %>%
  filter(CNT == "SGP")


# eval: false
write_rds(stu_qqq_SG,
          "data/stu_qqq_SG.rds")


# eval: false
stu_qqq_SG <-
  read_rds("data/stu_qqq_SG.rds")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7

Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE

title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
The name and function of the new packages that will be used for this exercise are as follow:

ggrepel: an R package provides a way to prevent labels from overlapping in ggplot2 plots.
ggthemes: an R package provides some extra themes, geoms, and scales for ‘ggplot2’.
hrbrthemes: an R package provides another set of visually appealing themes and formatting options for ggplot2.
patchwork: an R package provides a way to combine multiple ggplot2 plots into a single figure.



Code
# eval: false
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               ggrepel)







Code
# eval: false
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
The name and function of the new packages that will be used for this exercise are as follow:

ggrepel: an R package provides a way to prevent labels from overlapping in ggplot2 plots.
ggthemes: an R package provides some extra themes, geoms, and scales for ‘ggplot2’.
hrbrthemes: an R package provides another set of visually appealing themes and formatting options for ggplot2.
patchwork: an R package provides a way to combine multiple ggplot2 plots into a single figure.



Code
# eval: false
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               ggrepel)

title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
2.1 Working with ggrepel package
ggrepel is an extension of ggplot2 package which provides geoms for ggplot2 to repel overlapping text as in our examples on the right.


Code
# eval: false
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm,
              linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID),
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
2.2 Working with themes
8 Built-in themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_classic(), theme_dark(), theme_light(), theme_linedraw(), theme_minimal(), and theme_void(). Refer to here


Code
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Ditribution of Maths scores")






2.2.1 Working with ggthems package
In the example below, The Economist theme is used.


Code
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_economist() +
  ggtitle("Ditribution of Maths scores")







2.2.2 Working with hrbthems package
hrbrthemesThis focuses more on the typographic elements, labels and fonts.


Code
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()





The second goal centers around productivity for a production workflow. In fact, this “production workflow” is the context for where the elements of hrbrthemes should be used.


Code
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18,          #increase font size of the axis title to 18
              base_size = 15,                #increase the default axis label to 15
              grid = "Y") +                  #only keep the y-axis grid line -> remove the x-axis grid lines
  ggtitle("Ditribution of Maths scores")

title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
2.3 Working with patchwork
Creating composite plot by combining multiple graphs. Start with creating three statistical graphics below.


Code
#creating histogram
p1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Ditribution of Maths scores")

p2 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Ditribution of English scores")

#creating scatterplot
p3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm,
              linewidth = 0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")


Creating patchwork.(Refer here for more details)

Use ‘+’ sign to create two columns layout
Use ‘/’ sign to create two row layout (stack)
Use ‘()’ sign to create subplot group
Use ‘|’ sign to place the plots besisde each other

Example 1


Code
p1 + p2 / p3





Example 2


Code
(p1 / p2) | p3





Example 3: It will auto-tag the subplots in text


Code
((p1 / p2) | p3) +
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')





Example 4: Combine patchwork and themes


Code
((p1 / p2) | p3) & theme_economist()





Example 5: Insert another plot in a plot using insert_element()


Code
p3 + inset_element(p2,
                   left = 0.02,
                   bottom = 0.7,
                   right = 0.5,
                   top = 1)

text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications. In this website, you will find my coursework prepared for this course.

title: Take-home_Ex01
text:
1.OVERVIEW
Despite official claims of educational equity in Singapore, public perception highlights persistent disparities based on socioeconomic status, school type, and family background.
2.OBJECTIVE
Using appropriate Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) methods and ggplot2 functions to get insight.

The distribution of Singapore students’ performance in mathematics, reading, and science.
The relationship between these performances with schools, gender and socioeconomic status of the students.

3.DATA PREPARATION
3.1 Loading R packages


Code
pacman::p_load(tidyverse,haven)


3.2 Data set
As we are foucesd on Singapore database. So firstly we should filter Singapore dataset. Refer to In-class Exercise 1 for more details


Code
# eval: false
stu_qqq_SG <-
  read_rds("data/stu_qqq_SG.rds")


3.3 Data Preparation


Code
grep("PV", colnames(stu_qqq_SG), value = TRUE)
